results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.
results.title_for_label: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

00:03:22:00 – Harold Drayton, Mrs Drayton, Mr Drayton, Mrs Lowe, Mrs Hargraves part of the Sunshine cruise passengers drinking from coconuts

00:03:56:00 – Dance Performances and music, St George Browns College, Raboul

00:07:03:00 – George Brown College boys and girls, performing marching exercises, rhythm exercises with coconut shells and sticks, Raboul

00:09:40:00 – Passengers of the cruise on a hike with sun umbrellas, Raboul

00:09:56:00 – Man sitting on Tortoise as it tries to move, Raboul

00:11:12:00 – Cruise passengers posing with local men

00:11:14:00 – local man with spear and Axe

00:11:53:00 – local man performs a banned Duk-Duk-dance

00:13:45:00 – Farewelled by village locals, New Britain, boats point of view

00:14:26:00 – Arriving at a new village (unidentified) New Britain with local students in uniform and drums being played to welcome the tourists

results.title: The Thief of Baghdad
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure. He climbs clouds, battles sea-creatures and killer plants, defeats the Mongols with an army of dust, rides a winged horse and finally becomes victorious. This silent classic is a much loved children’s film.

results.title: The Soundmaker (2004)
results.material_description:
3-channel film installation
Colour, sound
Loop, 35 min 7 sec
While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making.
results.brief_description: The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description:
The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals. In each case the protagonist is caught up in a microcosm that suggests mental and spatial claustrophobia. As a reaction to the hopeless situation, he plunges into permanent Sisyphean activity – going nowhere and producing nothing. The motifs of perpetual attempt and constant failure find their equivalent in the repetitive structure of the loop. The scenes are allegories of our frantic and ultimately futile attempts to escape the surrounding norms, constraints, structures and rituals by which we are determined.

The Soundmaker piles, in endless iteration, the furnishings of his room into his own personal Tower of Babel, only to dismantle it and return the room to its original state again. His performance is accompanied by a Foley artist, an alter ego looking identical to himself. While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making. Shot in aerial and frontal perspective, the screens depict the translation from life as it occurs in the centre into simple objects and minimal movements. As in many of his latter projects, Rosefeldt reflects upon the myth machinery of cinema by showing the film set behind the scenes, while simultaneously using it as a metaphor for the mechanics of life.

Summarised from Stefan Berg and Katerina Gregos, in: Julian Rosefeldt: Film Works (2008).

  • https://www.julianrosefeldt.com/

As a reaction to the hopeless situation, he plunges into permanent Sisyphean activity – going nowhere and producing nothing. The motifs of perpetual attempt and constant failure find their equivalent in the repetitive structure of the loop. The scenes are allegories of our frantic and ultimately futile attempts to escape the surrounding norms, constraints, structures and rituals by which we are determined.

results.title: Turbulent
results.brief_description: Turbulent is a two-screen film installation by famous Iranian artist Shirin Neshat. It is among her most critically acclaimed works, having won her a Lion d’Or at the Venice Biennale back in 1999.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: Two-channel video installation. A man performs and is applauded on one screen. On the second screen a woman begins to sing disrupting and challenging the male space.
description_for_label: Two-channel video installation. A man performs and is applauded on one screen. On the second screen a woman begins to sing disrupting and challenging the male space.

images.credit_line: Shirin Neshat – Turbulent, 1998, black-and-white video installation, installation view, Lahore Biennale, 2018, photo: Usman Saqib Zuberi/lahorebiennale.org
images.alt_text: An installation view of a screen-based artwork that features a black and white image of a bearded man, with people seated in a purple room watching it

results.title: Untitled Goose Game
results.brief_description: Untitled Goose Game is a slapstick-stealth-sandbox, where you are a goose let loose on an unsuspecting village. Make your way around town, from peoples’ back gardens to the high street shops to the village green, setting up pranks, stealing hats, honking a lot, and generally ruining everyone’s day.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description:
It’s a lovely morning in the village and you are a horrible goose.

Untitled Goose Game is a slapstick-stealth-sandbox, where you are a goose let loose on an unsuspecting village. Make your way around town, from peoples’ back gardens to the high street shops to the village green, setting up pranks, stealing hats, honking a lot, and generally ruining everyone’s day.

results.title: Somebody that I used to know
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.

constellations_primary.name: Viral music videos
constellations_primary.description: Gotye's 'Somebody that I used to know' was one of the internet's most viral music videos, seconded only to Queen Bey's 'Singles Ladies'.

results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

images.alt_text: A close-up of Gotye, who has slightly pink lips and chestnut curly shoulder length hair, he's squinting

results.title: Coraline
results.brief_description: Coraline lets players take on the role of the adventurous heroine Coraline and interact with the wondrous characters from the movie while navigating the scheming Other Mother’s web of deceit in a fantastical adventure through two distinct and interactive worlds.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

results.description: Coraline lets players take on the role of the adventurous heroine Coraline and interact with the wondrous characters from the movie while navigating the scheming Other Mother’s web of deceit in a fantastical adventure through two distinct and interactive worlds. Players engage in unique mini-games and adventures with Coraline’s friends Wybie and Cat as they collect items that will unlock the mysteries of the Other World.
description_for_label: Coraline lets players take on the role of the adventurous heroine Coraline and interact with the wondrous characters from the movie while navigating the scheming Other Mother’s web of deceit in a fantastical adventure through two distinct and interactive worlds.
